echoes.author: John Locke
echoes.connection: Your dream's unsettling experience of not remembering your own name and losing your place resonates with Locke's philosophical inquiry into how memory and consciousness are fundamental to maintaining a stable sense of self.
echoes.context: Locke's theory posits that personal identity is based on continuous consciousness and memory; if memory fails, one's sense of self is fundamentally challenged.
echoes.text: For, since consciousness always accompanies thinking, and 'tis that that makes every one to be what he calls self, and thereby distinguishes himself from all other thinking things, in this alone consists personal identity...

echoes.author: Salvador DalÃ­
echoes.connection: The distorted and flooded landscape of your dream finds a visual parallel in DalÃ­'s surrealist works, reflecting how art has historically captured the illogical and unsettling nature of subconscious experiences.
echoes.context: DalÃ­'s art frequently explored the subconscious through bizarre and dream-like imagery, challenging conventional reality and perception.
echoes.text: 'The Persistence of Memory' (painting) depicts a dream world where melting clocks and distorted landscapes challenge perception, embodying the illogical fluidity of the subconscious.

echoes.author: Michel de Montaigne
echoes.connection: Your dream's revelation that perceived 'awful flaws' were not so bad echoes Montaigne's extensive self-examination, where he demonstrated how honest introspection can lead to a more accepting and less judgmental view of one's own imperfections.
echoes.context: Montaigne pioneered the essay form, deeply exploring self-reflection and candidly revealing his own imperfections, suggesting that honest self-assessment often reduces the perceived severity of flaws.
echoes.text: I set forth myself naked, as I am... I could wish to represent things in my own fashion, and to have my own being known, such as it is.

echoes.author: Japanese Aesthetics (Wabi-sabi)
echoes.connection: The contrast in your dream between the filthy house and the pristine balcony resonates with the Japanese aesthetic of Wabi-sabi, which teaches finding beauty and peace within imperfection and the natural processes of decay and simplicity.
echoes.context: Wabi-sabi is an aesthetic concept that values the beauty of imperfection, transience, and natural decay, finding serenity in worn or modest objects and spaces.
echoes.text: Wabi-sabi embraces imperfection, transience, and the beauty found in natural decay and simplicity, often valuing the humble and unrefined qualities of things.

echoes.author: SÃ¸ren Kierkegaard
echoes.connection: Your dream's feeling of being 'not in your place' while surrounded by a host of 'their' friends mirrors Kierkegaard's profound reflections on the individual's inherent isolation and the search for authentic selfhood amidst the anonymity of the crowd.
echoes.context: Kierkegaard emphasized the importance of individual existence and responsibility, often portraying the crowd as a means of escaping authentic selfhood, leading to a sense of alienation for the genuine individual.
echoes.text: The crowd is untruth, and to truly become oneself, one must often stand apart, facing the profound isolation of individual existence.

echoes.author: Ecclesiastes (Book of Kohelet)
echoes.connection: The recurring sensation in your dream of being forgotten and displacedâ€”the 'again' (×©×•×‘) â€“ echoes the ancient wisdom of Ecclesiastes, which suggests that many human experiences and feelings are not new but part of timeless, cyclical patterns.
echoes.context: This biblical book explores the cyclical nature of life, human experience, and futility, emphasizing that many struggles and patterns are timeless.
echoes.text: What has been will be again, what has been done will be done again; there is nothing new under the sun.

echoes.author: Matsuo BashÅ
echoes.connection: Just as BashÅ found a moment of quiet contemplation in the recurring image of a crow, your daily encounter with the same crow on the street highlights how even mundane urban routines can offer moments of familiarity and observation.
echoes.context: BashÅ often observed nature in his poetry, finding profound meaning in simple, recurring sights within his daily life.
echoes.text: On a withered branch / A crow has settled / Autumn evening.

echoes.author: Heraclitus
echoes.connection: Your observation of the sea subtly approaching the city mirrors Heraclitus's ancient insight that the world is in a constant state of flux, with changes often occurring without our direct awareness of their process.
echoes.context: Heraclitus, an ancient Greek philosopher, emphasized the constant, underlying change in the natural world, a concept known as 'flux'.
echoes.text: Everything flows and nothing abides; everything gives way and nothing stays fixed.

echoes.author: Virginia Woolf
echoes.connection: Your feeling of your hat becoming too big reflects a sense of internal disproportion or a shifting identity, much like Virginia Woolf's attempts to solidify her own sense of self amidst life's changes.
echoes.context: Virginia Woolf's diaries frequently reflect her inner struggles with identity, mental health, and the elusive nature of the self as she navigated her personal and artistic life.
echoes.text: I am trying to make myself a little more solid.

echoes.author: Hippocrates
echoes.connection: Your keen awareness of unseen allergens in the air echoes Hippocrates' ancient medical insights into how the atmosphere and environmental conditions subtly but profoundly influence human health.
echoes.context: Hippocrates, often called the 'Father of Medicine,' was among the first to systematically observe and theorize about the impact of environmental factors, including air quality, on human health.
echoes.text: From the air, and particularly from the weather, come diseases.

echoes.author: Samuel Pepys
echoes.connection: Your repeated encounter with the crow, a small but consistent part of your day, mirrors Samuel Pepys' meticulous documentation of the daily routines that, in their recurrence, define the rhythm and meaning of life.
echoes.context: Samuel Pepys' extensive diary meticulously records the daily routines and observations of life in 17th-century London, revealing how recurring events shape one's perception and experience.
echoes.text: And so to bed, after another day of business and pleasure.

echoes.author: RenÃ© Magritte
echoes.connection: Your unique observations, like the 'kind slaves' or the sea subtly approaching, echo RenÃ© Magritte's art, which similarly challenged conventional perceptions and revealed the subjective, often surreal, nature of reality.
echoes.context: RenÃ© Magritte's surrealist artwork often questioned the nature of reality and representation, inviting viewers to look beyond the obvious and perceive the world from a new, often perplexing, perspective.
echoes.text: Ceci n'est pas une pipe.

echoes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
echoes.connection: This echoes your resolve to cultivate your unique inner world, reminding you that true strength comes from trusting your own path and not seeking external validation for your deepest self.
echoes.context: Emerson's essay advocates for individualism and self-reliance, encouraging people to trust their own thoughts and intuitions rather than conforming to societal pressures.
echoes.text: "Trust thyself: every heart vibrates to that iron string." - from Self-Reliance.
triggeringKeywords: Is there any use in showing?

echoes.author: Mary Wollstonecraft
echoes.connection: Your feeling of being "a curse" as a single woman resonates with historical critiques of societal pressures that often confined women's worth to their marital status, a theme Wollstonecraft passionately challenged.
echoes.context: Wollstonecraft argued for women's education and rationality, criticizing the societal expectation for women to be solely focused on marriage and domesticity.
echoes.text: "It is time to effect a revolution in female mannersâ€”time to restore to them their lost dignityâ€”and make them, as a part of the human species, labour by improving their reason to become more excellent."

echoes.author: Matsuo BashÅ
echoes.connection: Your turning towards the sun on your cheek mirrors the timeless wisdom found in BashÅ's haiku, highlighting how profound peace and contentment can be found in the quiet, simple moments of nature.
echoes.context: A classic haiku by BashÅ, embodying the Zen aesthetic of finding profound beauty and tranquility in simple, transient moments of nature.
echoes.text: "Old pond... a frog jumps in... sound of water."

echoes.author: Marcus Aurelius
echoes.connection: Your reflection that 'everything is okay' despite varying degrees of 'okayness' aligns with the Stoic practice of acknowledging life's challenges while asserting control over one's internal response to them.
echoes.context: Marcus Aurelius's Meditations are a series of personal writings on Stoic philosophy, emphasizing the importance of controlling one's perceptions and maintaining inner tranquility amidst external chaos.
echoes.text: "If you are distressed by anything external, the pain is not due to the thing itself, but to your estimate of it; and this you have the power to revoke at any moment."

echoes.author: Rainer Maria Rilke
echoes.connection: Your declaration of feeling 'different' and the intention to turn towards the sun echoes Rilke's powerful call for personal transformation, a recognition that growth demands an active shift in one's path.
echoes.context: This famous concluding line from Rilke's poem is an imperative to self-transformation, suggesting that encountering profound beauty or truth demands a fundamental change in one's existence.
echoes.text: "You must change your life." - from Archaic Torso of Apollo.
triggeringKeywords: I don't feel like that anymore
turn my whole face towards it

echoes.author: Henry David Thoreau
echoes.connection: Your meticulous building of an 'inner world like an ant farm' resonates with Thoreau's deliberate pursuit of a life stripped down to its essentials, focused on rich internal experience rather than external accumulation.
echoes.context: Thoreau's account of living simply in a cabin by Walden Pond, advocating for self-sufficiency, introspection, and a deliberate engagement with life, often by cultivating one's inner world away from societal distractions.
echoes.text: "I went to the woods because I wished to live deliberately, to front only the essential facts of life, and see if I could not learn what it had to teach, and not, when I came to die, discover that I had not lived." - from Walden.

echoes.author: Emily Dickinson
echoes.connection: This poem echoes your feeling of "standing in the corner" and feeling overlooked, suggesting that even in such isolation, there can be a quiet solidarity with others who share a similar unseen existence.
echoes.context: Dickinson's poem captures the essence of feeling like an outsider or an "unseen" individual, yet finding solace in the idea of shared solitude.
echoes.text: I'm nobody! Who are you? / Are you nobody, too? / Then there's a pair of us - don't tell! / They'd banish us, you know.

echoes.author: Book of Job
echoes.connection: Your cry "××” ×§×•×¨×” ×œ×œ×‘ ×©×œ×™? ×•×œ××” ×›×›×”?" resonates deeply with Job's ancient lament, reflecting a universal human need to question the source and purpose of profound personal suffering, even while acknowledging a higher power.
echoes.context: Job's desperate cry questions the very purpose of his existence and suffering, directly addressing a higher power with his anguish.
echoes.text: Why did I not perish at birth, and die as I came from the womb? Why were there knees to receive me and breasts for me to nurse? For now I would be lying in peace; I would be asleep and at rest.

echoes.author: Rumi
echoes.connection: Your reflection on the heart's ability to "empty and fill again" and its need for a "light breeze" for respite finds a profound echo in Rumi's "Guest House" poem, which embraces the cyclical nature of emotions and the continuous process of internal renewal.
echoes.context: Rumi's poem uses the metaphor of a guest house to describe the human heart's capacity to host all emotions, even the painful ones, seeing them as part of a continuous process that can ultimately lead to new understanding or joy.
echoes.text: This being human is a guest house. Every morning a new arrival. A joy, a depression, a meanness, some momentary awareness comes as an unexpected visitor. Welcome and entertain them all! Even if they are a crowd of sorrows, who violently sweep your house empty of its furniture, still, treat each guest honorably. He may be clearing you out for some new delight.

echoes.author: Anne Frank
echoes.connection: Your longing for a "light breeze" and to "produce a leaf or two" amidst your struggles deeply resonates with Anne Frank's ability to find moments of vital hope and renewal in the simple endurance of nature, even in the direst circumstances.
echoes.context: Written while hiding during the Holocaust, Anne Frank found profound solace and a sense of enduring hope by connecting with the small natural phenomena she could observe from her window.
echoes.text: I firmly believe that nature can bring comfort to all in suffering. I looked up at the blue sky and the bare chestnut tree, on whose branches little raindrops glistened, and saw the seagulls and other birds soaring in the wind. As long as this exists, and I may live to see it, this sunshine, this cloudless sky, while I may draw breath, then there is no cause for despair.

echoes.author: Sojourner Truth
echoes.connection: Your feeling of "standing in the corner" despite knowing you're "not the only daughter" resonates with Sojourner Truth's powerful assertion of her presence and worth, highlighting the historical struggle of individuals, especially women, to be fully seen and acknowledged rather than marginalized.
echoes.context: Sojourner Truth's powerful speech at the Women's Rights Convention challenged the prevailing notions of gender and race, asserting her full humanity and demanding recognition for her strength and contributions, despite being marginalized.
echoes.text: I have ploughed and reaped and hoed and chopped and mowed, and can any man do more than that? I have heard much about the sexes being equal; I can carry as much as any man, and can eat as much too, if I can get it. I am as strong as any man that is now.

echoes.author: Jean-Baptiste Alphonse Karr
echoes.connection: Your vivid image of the heart being knocked over "again by a fat cat" after trying to "produce a leaf or two" powerfully evokes the sentiment of "the more things change, the more they stay the same," highlighting the enduring, sometimes frustrating, return of life's challenges.
echoes.context: This famous French aphorism observes the cyclical nature of events and human behavior, suggesting that despite apparent changes, fundamental patterns and challenges often recur.
echoes.text: Plus Ã§a change, plus c'est la mÃªme chose.

echoes.author: Elie Wiesel
echoes.context: Wiesel's harrowing account of his experiences as a prisoner in Auschwitz and Buchenwald during the Holocaust, exploring the depths of human cruelty and the profound questioning of faith and divine presence amidst unimaginable suffering.
echoes.text: Never shall I forget that night, the first night in camp, which has turned my life into one long night, seven times cursed and seven times sealed.

echoes.author: Unknown (Biblical)
echoes.context: The story of Job, a righteous man who endures immense suffering and loss, prompting a profound debate on the nature of divine justice and human resilience in the face of inexplicable adversity and perceived divine neglect.
echoes.text: Naked I came from my mother's womb, and naked I shall return there. The Lord gave and the Lord has taken away. Blessed be the name of the Lord.

echoes.author: Viktor Frankl
echoes.context: Frankl's logotherapy, based on his experiences as a Holocaust survivor, posits that finding meaning in life, even in suffering, is the primary motivational force for humans. He highlighted the importance of acts of kindness and human connection even in the most inhumane conditions, magnifying their value.
echoes.text: Everything can be taken from a man but one thing: the last of the human freedomsâ€”to choose oneâ€™s attitude in any given set of circumstances, to choose oneâ€™s own way.

echoes.author: Traditionally Jeremiah
echoes.context: A poetic book mourning the destruction of Jerusalem and the First Temple. It vividly describes collective grief, suffering, and the questioning of divine action, reflecting the deep sorrow of a people in exile and resonating with the idea of a shared divine suffering.
echoes.text: My eyes are spent with weeping; my stomach churns; my liver is poured out on the ground because of the destruction of the daughter of my people, because infants and babies are fainting in the streets of the city.

echoes.author: Rabbi Levi Yitzchak of Berditchev
echoes.context: A famous, almost defiant, plea from a Hasidic master to God, challenging divine justice and advocating fiercely for the Jewish people, while simultaneously expressing profound love and faith. It embodies the audacious intimacy and shared suffering often found in Jewish spirituality.
echoes.text: Master of the Universe! I, Levi Yitzchak, son of Sarah, come before You. What do You want from Your people Israel? Why do You persecute them so?

echoes.author: Rabbinic Sages
echoes.context: Various Midrashic texts describe God literally weeping over the destruction of the Temple and the exile of the Jewish people, symbolizing divine empathy and shared grief in the face of national catastrophe. This directly parallels the new entry's imagery of God weeping during the Holocaust.
echoes.text: When the Holy One, Blessed be He, remembered His children who were exiled, He wept, saying, 'Woe is to the father who has banished his children from his table!'

echoes.author: Charles Dickens
echoes.connection: This reflects your sudden, visceral encounter with the "disgusting" and "stomach-turning" reality of the food delivery, akin to how people in historical urban centers often faced unpleasant sights and smells.
echoes.context: Dickens frequently depicted the grim realities of Victorian London, including its poor sanitation and the pervasive filth, which often evoked visceral reactions from its inhabitants and observers.
echoes.text: I have seen so much of the refuse and dirt of this great city, the very thought of it makes me sick.

echoes.author: Carl Linnaeus
echoes.connection: Your detailed examination of the "worms, slugs, headless crabs" to determine the correct order mirrors the meticulous, often repetitive, work of naturalists like Linnaeus who imposed order on strange and diverse biological data.
echoes.context: Linnaeus revolutionized biology with his systematic classification of living organisms, requiring meticulous observation and comparison of countless specimens, often of highly varied and strange forms.
echoes.text: Every plant, every animal, must have its proper place in the great scheme of nature, however minute or unusual.

echoes.author: Franz Kafka
echoes.connection: This echo resonates with the strange and almost bureaucratic task you faced, where the very nature of the problem (a restaurant specializing in 'horrifying creepy crawlies') highlights the absurdities that can arise in complex modern systems.
echoes.context: Kafka's works often explore themes of bureaucratic absurdity, alienation, and individuals grappling with overwhelming and illogical systems beyond their comprehension.
echoes.text: Someone must have been telling lies about Josef K., for without having done anything wrong he was arrested one fine morning.

echoes.author: Charles Darwin
echoes.connection: Your visceral reaction to the "disgusting" and "stomach-turning" 'sheratzim' echoes the historical discomfort experienced by many, including naturalists like Darwin, when encountering unfamiliar or what they perceived as unnatural food sources in different cultures.
echoes.context: During his voyage on the Beagle, Darwin encountered diverse cultures and their culinary practices, often noting the stark differences and his own reactions, sometimes of aversion, to unfamiliar foods.
echoes.text: The inhabitants of these parts partake of many curious dishes, some of which our European palates could scarcely endure.

echoes.author: Charles Baudelaire
echoes.connection: The mundane beginning of your journey on the U-Bahn, leading to the bizarre Wolt chat incident, reflects how everyday urban routines can unexpectedly unfold into moments of unsettling strangeness, a theme explored by observers of city life.
echoes.context: Baudelaire, as a flÃ¢neur, observed and captured the dynamic, often disorienting, and sometimes grotesque aspects of modern Parisian urban life, where the mundane could suddenly give way to the strange.
echoes.text: The city, in its ceaseless movements, can suddenly reveal the bizarre and the dreamlike amidst the everyday grind.

echoes.author: Edmund Burke / Immanuel Kant
echoes.connection: Just as Romantic philosophers found profound spiritual insight in the overwhelming power of nature, your morning weariness, a form of personal sublime, reveals a deeper appreciation for the divine order expressed in your own body.
echoes.context: Burke and Kant developed the concept of the 'sublime' as an aesthetic experience distinct from beauty, arising from confronting vastness or power that exceeds human comprehension, leading to a sense of both dread and spiritual elevation.
echoes.text: The sublime evokes awe and terror, yet elevates the spirit through its overwhelming power.

echoes.author: Plato
echoes.connection: Your distress over unspoken words and hidden knowledge mirrors Plato's cave dwellers, who suffered from the torment of mistaking mere shadows for reality, highlighting the human struggle with perceived versus actual truths.
echoes.context: In Plato's Allegory of the Cave, individuals confined in a cave only perceive shadows cast on a wall, believing them to be the true reality. The allegory illustrates the struggle to discern genuine knowledge from mere illusion or opinion.
echoes.text: Prisoners mistake shadows for reality, highlighting the deceptive nature of perception and the painful quest for truth.

echoes.author: Mahavira / Gautama Buddha
echoes.connection: Your compassionate impulse to preserve even the smallest life forms resonates with the ancient principle of Ahimsa, where reverence for all beings is paramount, even as you confront the quiet indifference of a world that sometimes feels as if it doesn't acknowledge your gaze.
echoes.context: Ahimsa, central to Jainism and Buddhism, is the ethical principle of not causing harm to any living thing, whether by thought, word, or deed. It emphasizes compassion and universal love for all forms of life, from humans to insects.
echoes.text: A principle of non-harm and reverence for all living beings, reflecting the interconnectedness of life.

echoes.author: Albert Camus (reinterpretation)
echoes.connection: Your dual state of curiosity and weariness, coupled with the recognition of endless work ahead, echoes Sisyphus, whose eternal task became a symbol of finding meaning and defiance in the ongoing, often exhausting, act of living.
echoes.context: In Greek myth, Sisyphus was punished by the gods with the task of rolling a boulder up a hill, only for it to roll down each time it neared the top, an eternal and fruitless effort. Albert Camus later reinterpreted this myth as an allegory for the human condition, suggesting that meaning can be found in embracing the absurd and the continuous struggle itself.
echoes.text: A king condemned to eternally push a boulder uphill, symbolizing absurd struggle yet finding meaning in rebellion.

echoes.author: Leonardo da Vinci
echoes.connection: Your admiration for your physique as proof of divine providence mirrors Leonardo da Vinci's pursuit of perfect human proportion, where the body's form became a canvas for demonstrating universal harmony and the divine order.
echoes.context: Leonardo da Vinci's 'Vitruvian Man' illustrates the perfect human body based on the writings of the Roman architect Vitruvius. It depicts a male figure in two superimposed positions with his limbs inscribed in a circle and square, symbolizing the harmony between human anatomy and the cosmos, and the belief in divine proportion.
echoes.text: A drawing representing the ideal human body proportions and its connection to universal design.

echoes.author: Carl von Clausewitz
echoes.connection: Your sickness from what you don't know, and the confusion over trust, mirrors the 'fog of war,' where the absence of clear information breeds profound anxiety and distorts perception in the battleground of human relationships.
echoes.context: Carl von Clausewitz, a Prussian general and military theorist, introduced the concept of 'friction' in war, with the 'fog of war' being a key component. It describes the inherent uncertainty, incomplete information, and psychological stresses (fear, doubt) that make warfare inherently unpredictable and opaque, hindering rational decision-making.
echoes.text: The pervasive uncertainty, doubt, and fear that obscure clear understanding and decision-making in conflict.

echoes.author: Ecclesiastes
echoes.context: This ancient biblical passage expresses a cyclical view of history and human experience, suggesting that fundamental truths and events recur, making reinterpretation a key to new insight.
echoes.text: What has been will be again, what has been done will be done again; there is nothing new under the sun.

echoes.author: Charles Dickens
echoes.context: The famous plea from the orphan Oliver Twist, embodying the desperate situation of neglected children in Victorian England.
echoes.text: Please, sir, I want some more.

echoes.author: Walt Whitman
echoes.context: Whitman's celebration of the individual self, acknowledging and embracing the vastness and often contradictory nature of human experience and identity.
echoes.text: Do I contradict myself? Very well then I contradict myself, (I am large, I contain multitudes.)

echoes.author: Rainer Maria Rilke
echoes.context: Rilke advises patience and introspection for an aspiring poet, suggesting that answers to deep questions emerge through living experience, akin to a natural blooming process.
echoes.text: Live the questions now. Perhaps you will then gradually, without noticing it, live along some distant day into the answer.

echoes.author: T.S. Eliot
echoes.context: Eliot argues that true originality isn't a rejection of the past, but a re-evaluation and re-ordering of tradition through the new work.
echoes.text: The existing monuments form an ideal order among themselves, which is modified by the introduction of the new (the really new) work of art among them.

echoes.author: Marshall McLuhan
echoes.context: McLuhan theorized that the form of a medium embeds itself in the message, altering how the message is perceived and understood, fundamentally shaping society.
echoes.text: The medium is the message.

echoes.author: Ecclesiastes (traditional author, Solomon)
echoes.context: This ancient wisdom text expresses a profound sense of the cyclical nature of existence, where human actions and experiences are endlessly repeated.
echoes.text: What has been will be again, what has been done will be done again; there is nothing new under the sun.

echoes.author: Louis XVII (via historical event)
echoes.context: The son of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette, he was separated from his family during the French Revolution and died in prison due to neglect and harsh conditions, his fate a symbol of an innocent life 'grown wild' by abandonment.
echoes.text: Abandoned and left to grow wild in the Temple prison, a tragic consequence of the revolution.

echoes.author: Mary Shelley
echoes.context: As the daughter of radical intellectuals Mary Wollstonecraft and William Godwin, Mary Shelley's identity was profoundly shaped by her unconventional upbringing and the intellectual legacy she inherited and reinterpreted, much like Sapir's self-identification through cultural figures.
echoes.text: The offspring of philosophical and literary giants, crafting narratives of creation and identity.

echoes.author: Ecclesiastes (traditional author, Solomon)
echoes.context: This verse reflects on the natural rhythm of life, emphasizing that there is an appointed time for everything, echoing Sapir's contemplation of 'blooming in time' with the seasons.
echoes.text: To everything there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven.

echoes.author: Walt Whitman
echoes.context: In 'Song of Myself,' Whitman embraces a multifaceted and often contradictory self, a 'multitude' of experiences and traits, resonating with Sapir's query about inheriting conflicting qualities like 'shyness, terribly crude.'
echoes.text: Do I contradict myself? Very well then I contradict myself, (I am large, I contain multitudes.)

echoes.author: Pablo Picasso
echoes.context: This famous quote, often attributed to Picasso, encapsulates the idea that originality in art and thought often comes not from pure invention, but from creatively reinterpreting, 'stealing' from, and re-contextualizing existing ideas, aligning with Sapir's belief in rephrasing as the path to significance.
echoes.text: Good artists copy, great artists steal.
